Ilja Preuss wrote:

> Ole Ersoy wrote:
> 
>  > The file loading part is in a private method, because
>  > the load routine is specific to the class that is
>  > being tested, and is therefore not useful in a utility
>  > library.
> 
> Reusability is not the only reason to extract things into their own
> classes, is it?

Even so, Ole's perspective is a little shortsighted. Extracting data 
from a file consists of two operations:

1. Loading file contents into memory, usually as lines of text.
2. Parsing the lines of text while in memory.

Part #1 is a perfect candidate for a reusable library. In Ruby, you 
simply say file.readlines(), for example. There's no reason to 
reimplement this the way we do in Java. (Does Java 5 have a built-in 
library method for loading a text file yet?!)

Part #2 is what's specific to your application, because it depends on 
how you formatted the text when you saved it. I could see that being a 
private method, perhaps, that takes a List of lines and parses them.

So it might be that the only reason the "loading" feature is not 
reusable is that Java hasn't made the reusable part reusable!
